pressure relief valves, monitors, and ammonia vessel level controls and safety interlocks are used in the refrigeration system.  The system can be operated or shut down locally or remotely from a cell phone or computer.  The computer system emails a daily report showing most conditions at a point every hour.

* Periodic inspection is performed on liquid level sensors, temperature and pressure instruments, switches and shutdown devices that have safety implications.

* Periodic inspections are performed for major powered equipment, including compressors, pumps and large fans, bearings, couplings, shaft seals, mountings, etc., for vibration or incipient mechanical failure.

* Proper design, including adherence to recognized safety codes, such as the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).

* Adherence to fire codes and preparation for fires, storms, or events which could impact the ammonia system.

* Prevention program compliance audits are performed every three years to verify that the elements are being properly implemented.  Any deficiency found in an audit is corrected.


3.0    ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have not been any accidents since Chairmans Foods purchased the facility; however, we did have a small release from the old system on May 11, 2022 where the control system failed resulting in a small release from a safety relief valves due to a high pressure situation.  The new ammonia refrigeration system has an excellent control system.

4.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Gordo's facility has implemented a detailed written Emergency Action Plan (EAP).  The EAP is intended to address all emergencies at the facility, in addition to incidents related to a release of ammonia.

The EAP includes awareness and response training for employees, coordination with the local fire department, coordination with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LERC), and evacuation of the facility and surrounding area.  The plan details what personal protective equi

ety and health effects of control system failures.  The PHA resulted in procedural and/or hardware recommendations to improve the safety and operation of the refrigeration system.  The PHA will be updated and revalidated every five years.

* Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  They also describe safe operating limits for temperature and pressure, the consequences of operating outside these safe operating limits, and a description of safety systems and how they operate.

* Refrigeration system operators receive refresher training at least every three years.  The training content is based upon the process safety information and operating procedures.  The training program ensures that the operators understand the nature and causes of problems arising from system operations and serves to increase awareness with respect to the hazards particular to ammonia and the refrigeration process.

* Events that might (or did) cause an accidental or unexpected release of ammonia are subjected to a formal investigation.  The objective of the investigation is to correct deficiencies in such a way as to prevent recurrence.

* Contractors that are hired to work on, or adjacent to, the refrigeration system are pre-qualified based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  

* Prior to the performance of any hot work (i.e., spark or flame producing operations such as welding, cutting, brazing, grinding), management must approve the work by executing a written hot work authorization permit to verify that precautions to prevent fire have been implemented.

* Replacement of all pressure relief valves occurs every five years.

* Numerous of safety systems, including

er evaporator for production and cold storage and a Quick Freeze Room for blast cooling product.  The system will operate at pressures from approximately 0 psi to 175 psi.  

The high side compressor suction draws from the intercooler (booster discharge) and the high side suction accumulator at about 25 psig.  The major discharge from the high side compressors (hot gas) is directed to the condensing towers.  A portion of the hot gas is also used for defrosting and for operation of the pumper drums.

The condensed liquid is returned to the high pressure receiver where it is fed to the low and high pressure equipment.   

2.0    PREVENTION PROGRAM

To help minimize the probability and severity of an ammonia release, a prevention program that meets OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA's Risk Management Program have been implemented.  The key components of the prevention program are summarized below:

* The development, documentation, and operator availability of critical process safety information regarding the hazards of ammonia, the design basis of the system, and the equipment.  This information is used to fully understand and safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.

* The development of an extensive employee participation program, which includes employees from all levels of the organization and from all areas within the plant (i.e., production and maintenance).  

* The performance of a formal process hazard analysis (PHA) re-validation in 2022, using the What-if... technique.  A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible saf

The Unilever Atlanta, Georgia margarine production facility was subject to the USEPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) for Accidental Chemical Release regulation (40 CFR 68) because it had a refrigeration system that contains more than the threshold quantity (10,000 pounds) of anhydrous ammonia (CAS Number 7664-41-7).

The EPA Facility Identifier number for Unilever is being maintained for Gordo's, LLC.  

Chairmans Foods has installed a new ammonia refrigeration system.  The new installation includes all stainless steel piping to prevent corrosion of the piping and reduce the potential for ammonia leaks.  The facility is to receive 8,000 pounds of anhydrous today and charge it into the new high pressure receiver and is scheduled to start up the system on September 24th & 25th, 2022.  Once the new system is up and running, the anhydrous ammonia from the old system will be pumped down into the new system by use of a couple of ammonia hoses.  We expect the total inventory to be 14,000 pounds.

The anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) refrigeration system is used to control the processing and storage temperature for cheese dips, Ready-to-Eat foods and related products.  It is a closed loop system that contains ammonia in various physical states (gas, liquid, and saturated vapor).  Most of the ammonia equipment is located in the Machinery Room.  The condensing tower, air handler unit, and a small quantity of piping are located outdoors.

Ammonia is the oldest and most common refrigerant in general industrial use throughout the world.  It is a high capacity refrigerant that operates at reasonable pressure.  Although exposure to ammonia is irritating and potentially toxic in large doses, personnel exposure to more than a small leak is rare because ammonia operates within a closed system of vessels, piping, and equipment.


1.2    PROCESS DESCRIPTION

The ammonia refrigeration system is a two-stage system consisting of a high pressure side and a low pressure side.  There are a numb

1.1    SOURCE
The plant was apparently built in 1955.  Lipton Tea produced pickled fruits, vegetables and dressings.  Lipton sold it to Unilever in 1971.  Unilever produced margarine under the brands Country Crock, Imperial and I can’t believe it’s not butter.  Unilever closed the facility on June 30, 2013.  There was a large ammonia refrigeration system with high and low stage compressors and suction traps installed in the basement.  There was an equipment auction and the screw compressors and some condensers were sold.  The equipment was removed with little concern for the condition the facility was left.  Ammonia lines ran all through the basement and were poorly marked.  Charley & Sons purchased the facility in February 2014 and began producing cheese sauces.  Charley & Sons used three reciprocal Vilter high stage compressors, a suction trap and transfer system and some of the ammonia lines running through the basement.  The refrigeration control system was by Hench Controls.  The control system at one time may have been “state of the art”, but the Hench Controls no longer supported ammonia refrigeration controls and the facility's understanding of the system was limited.  Chairmans Foods purchased the facility from Charley & Sons on May 17, 2021 and are operating it as Gordo's LLC.  At the time of the purchase, the ammonia inventory was said to be less than 10,000 pounds.  Chairmans Foods calculated the inventory to be 6,345 pounds.  Chairmans Foods proceeded to build a new Machinery Room and discontinue use of all the refrigeration equipment, including the ammonia lines, located in the basement.  The only existing refrigeration equipment remaining to be are all the evaporators in the cooler, two evaporators in the RTE Pack-off Room and one air handlers located outside.  There is one existing ammonia condenser and two air handler units located outside that could be used in the future, but for now they are not connected to the new ammonia refrigeration system.
